questions.text: When should folic acid supplementation start in order to be effective in preventing neural tube defects?

choices.text: As soon as pregnancy is diagnosed
At least one month before conception

questions.solution:
• To be effective, folic acid supplementation should be started at least 1 month before conception, and continued through the first 2-3 months of pregnancy.
  • All women desirous of becoming pregnant should consume 400-800 μg folic acid daily; the dose is 4 mg/ day in those having delivered a child with neural tube defect.

questions.text: False statement about febrile convulsions is:

choices.text: Absence of a history of prior afebrile seizures
Associated with temperature of 38°C or higher
Antipyretics reduce the risk of recurrent febrile convulsions

questions.solution:
Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizure because the seizure often occurs as the temperature is rising or falling abruptly.

Febrile seizures are seizures:

  • That occur between the age of 6months and 5years
  • With a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • That are not the result of central nervous system infection or any metabolic imbalance
  • That which occur in the absence of a history of prior afebrile seizures
    • Tthere is no post ictal neurological deficit
  • Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizure because the seizure often occurs as the temperature is rising or falling.

questions.text: A child of age 5 years presents with developmental delay and multiple seizure types. The seizures could not be controlled with multiple drugs. EEG shows1-2 Hz spike and slow waves and polyspike bursts in sleep. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.

It typically starts between the ages of 2 and 10 years of age. Consists of a triad of

    • Developmental delay
    • Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures)
    • EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike–and– slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness

 

Patients commonly have myoclonic, atonic, and other seizure types that are difficult to control, and most are left with long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.

Other options:

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome) typically, it starts in early adolescence (NOT in childhood). The EEG usually shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike–and–slow- wave discharges (NOT 1-2 Hz spike–and– slow waves)

Landau-Kleffner syndrome is a rare condition characterized by loss of language skills attributed to auditory agnosia in a previously normal child (NOT a child with developmental delay)

West syndrome starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months (NOT in childhood). Typical EEG picture called hypsarrhythmia (NOT 1-2 Hz spike–and– slow waves, polyspike bursts)

questions.text: A 10 month old child presents with 2 weeks history of fever, vomiting and alteration of sensorium. Cranial CT scan reveals basal exudates and hydrocephalus, the most likely etiological agent is
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests tuberculous meningitis.

Characteristic features are:

  • Insidious onset of fever
  • Raised ICT
  • Basal exudates and Hydrocephalus on CT scan

questions.text: Gelastic seizures are associated with
questions.solution:
Gelastic seizures are characteristically associated with hypothalamic hamartoma.

Gelastic seizures :

  • Epileptic events characterised by bouts of laughter.
  • Autonomic features are present.
  • Hypothalamic hamartomas present with triad of :
    • Gelastic epilepsy
    • Precocious puberty
    • Developmental delay

questions.text: The earliest indicator of response after starting iron therapy in a 6 year old with iron deficiency is
questions.solution:
• Reticulocyte count is the earliest to rise after starting iron therapy.
  • This is followed by elevation of haemoglobin levels.
  • Body iron stores are repleted after the correction of haemoglobin levels.

questions.text: In which of the following disease the given appearance of calves is seen ?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Pseudohypertrophy of the calves. This is characteristic of Duchenne Muscular dystrophy.
  • In DMD due to the weakness of proximal thigh muscles there is compensatory hypertrophy of the distal calf muscle.
  • This is pseudo hypertrophy as there is only a deposition of fat and connective tissue and not true hypertrophy of muscles.

questions.text: A 1 year old child presents with features of hypotonia. On examination , he has tongue fasciculations, normal intelligence , keeps his body in a frog like position. The most likely diagnosis would be
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests Floppy Infant syndrome.

Spinal muscular atrophy is a genetic disease characterized by progressive degeneration of anterior horn cells, which results in weakness.

Among the causes of Floppy Infant syndrome, Spinal muscular atrophy is the best choice as:

  • Intelligence is normal
  • Tongue fasciculations

Other options :

  • Down’s syndrtome – Intelligence impaired
  • Guillian barre – Acute condition with history of fever or viral infections.

questions.text: An 8 year old boy presented with fever and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy with prior history of sore throat. There was no hepatomegaly. The peripheral blood smear shows > 20 % lympho plasmacytoid cells. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests Infectious Mononucleosis

Features of Infectious Mononucleosi :

  • Cervical Lymphadenopathy
  • Fever
  • History of sore throat
  • >20% atypical lymphocytes

Hepatomegaly may be absent (Occurs only in 30 % of cases)

questions.text: All of the following are used in diagnosis of HIV in a 2 month old child except
questions.solution:
HIV ELISA cannot be used in diagnosis of HIV in a child upto 18 months of age.

  • This is because all neonates born to HIV infected mothers will have IgG antibody in their blood regardless of their infection status.
  • So up until 18 months of age they will continue to test positive. Hence HIV ELISA should not be used.

questions.text: Sandifer syndrome due to GERD in infants is most often confused with ?
questions.solution:
• Abnormal or Dystonic neck posturing in Sandifer syndrome is most often confused with Seizures.
  • Posturing in Sandifer syndrome occurs 1 hour after feeding, and babies frequently have a history of vomiting, failure to thrive and repeated chest infections.

questions.text: Test done  to diagnose syphilis in newborn if mother is syphilitic is
questions.solution: Syphilis captia M test is an Enzyme immunoassay used to detect syphilis in newborn if the mother is syphilitic.

questions.text: First sign of puberty in a female is
questions.solution:
Thelarche is the first sign of puberty in girls.

  • Beginning of secondary breast development at onset of puberty
  • Tanner stage 2
  • Due to increased levels of Estradiol

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac lesions are expected in the patient seen in the image?
questions.solution:
This is a patient with a webbed neck, seen typically in Turner’s syndrome.

Turner’s syndrome:

  • Also known as Ullrisch- Turner syndrome or ‘Gonadal dysgenesis’ – Caused by absence of set of genes from the short arm of X chromosome ( 45XO )
  • Breast development is absent with ovarian failure and primary or secondary amenorrhea.
  • Lymphadema, short stature
  • Low set ears, low hairline and webbed neck
  • Horse shoe kidney
  • Cardiac manifestations – Coarctation of aorta, bicuspid aortic valve
  • Treatment – GH, Estrogen replacement therapy

questions.text: Lesion in the given figure is caused by:
questions.solution:
The lesion shown is Bullous Impetigo

  • Bullous impetigo is mainly an infection of infants and young children, caused by Staph aureus strains that produce exfoliative toxins, such as ETA, ETB, and ETD.
  • These toxins blister the superficial epidermis by hydrolyzing human desmoglein 1, resulting in a subcorneal vesicle – Localized staphylococcal skin syndrome.
  • Lesions develop most commonly on skin of the face, buttocks, trunk, perineum, and extremities

questions.text: Most common cause of acute diarrhoea in paediatric age group in India is :
questions.solution:
Rotavirus infection is the most common cause of diarrhoea in all children <5years of age.

Other agents are:

  • E.coli – second most common cause
  • Campylobacter jejuni
  • Salmonella
  • Shigella

questions.text: Commonest cause of obstructive hydrocephalus in children
questions.solution:
Etiology of Hyrocephalus :

  • Obstructive /non-communicating hydrocephalus develops most commonly in children due to Aqueductal stenosis.
  • Non-obstructive hydrocephalus most commonly occurs due to subarachnoid hemorrhage which is usually a result of intraventricular hemorrhage in a preterm infant.
Communicating/non-obstructive Non-communicating/obstructive
Post meningitic Aqueductal stenosis
Post haemorrhagic Dandy Walker/Chiari malformation
Choroid plexuses papilloma Tuberculosis

questions.text: Automatism is seen in all except
questions.solution:
• Infantile spasm doesn't present with automatism
  • Automatism are the characteristic feature of Complex partial seizures.
  • Automatisms are automatic semi purposeful movements of mouth (oral,alimentary such as chewing) or of the extremities (eg.manipulation of sheets/walking).

questions.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia in a female child, with the feature shown in the image is due to deficiency of?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts features of congenital virilization seen in congenital adrenal hyperplasia with 21-hydroxylase deficiency 

Features:

  • Group of autosomal recessive disorders caused by deficiency of enzymes responsible for synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone such as 21-hydroxylase, 11-beta-hydroxylase, or 3-beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase.
  • Deficiency of 21-hydroxylase, resulting from mutations or deletions of CYP21A, is the most common form of CAH, accounting for more than 90% of cases.
  • Females with mild 21-hydroxylase deficiency are identified later in childhood because of precocious pubic hair, clitoromegaly, or both, often accompanied by accelerated growth and skeletal maturation (simple virilizing adrenal hyperplasia).
  • Males with 21-hydroxylase deficiency have normal genitalia
  • Lab diagnosis – decreased cortisol, increased ACTH,17-hydroxyprogesterone, plasma rennin, serum androgens
  • Treatment – Glucocorticoid replacement

questions.text: The newborn cardiac output is
questions.solution:
The newborn cardiac output is 350ml/kg/min.

Age Cardiac output(ml/kg/min)
Fetus 450
Newborn 350
1-2 months of life 150
Adult 75

questions.text: 1 and ½ year old child with history of chronic diarrhea was brought to the hospital with complaints of perioral and perineal rash. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acrodermatitis enteropathica:

  • Autosomal recessive disorder seen in infants due to defect in intestinal zinc specific transporter – Human ZIP4 protein
  • Genetic locus – Chromosome 8q24.3
  • Classically presents while weaning from breast milk to formula, which has lower zinc bioavailability than breast milk.
  • C/F – Perioral and perineal rashes, periungal dermatitis- Beau’s lines on nails, chronic diarrhea, alopecia.
  • Labs – Low serum zinc, ALP
  • Paneth cell inclusion in intestinal mucosal biopsy
  • Treatment – Zinc – 50mg/ day for infants, upto 150mg/day for children

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy?
questions.solution:
Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). 

CP is an upper motor neuron disease characterized by rigidity and scissoring gait. Flaccid paralysis would be seen in lower motor neuron disease. 

Other options:

Option A: Hypotonia is a characteristic feature of athetoid CP. These infants generally have poor head control. 

Option B: Microcephaly can be seen in CP due to perinatal insults to the developing brain. 

Option C: Ataxia is a common feature of extrapyramidal CP.

The subtypes of cerebral palsy are given in the table below: 

Types Etiology Presentation MRI findings

Spastic

(m/c type)

Diplegia

(second m/c in India)

Prematurity

Ischemia 

Infection

Bilateral spasticity (LL>UL)

Scissoring gait

Commando crawl

Learning disabilities

 

 Periventricular leukomalacia
Hemiplegia

Vascular insult

Infection

Genetic

 

Early hand preference

(UL>LL)

Walking delayed up to 18-24m

Equinovarus deformity of foot

Seizures (33%)

 

Porencephalic cyst

Focal infarct changes

Quadriplegia

(most severe)

(m/c type in India)

Ischemia

Infection

Marked motor impairment

Flexion contractures

Strong association with seizures 

Severe intellectual impairment and GDD

Difficulty swallowing (supranuclear palsy)

Multi-cystic encephalomalacia

Severe periventricular leukomalacia

Dyskinetic

(15-20%)

Extrapyramidal

Athetoid

Chorioathetoid

Asphyxia

Kernicterus

Mitochondrial

Genetic

 

Rigidity/hypotonia, dystonia, athetosis, chorea

Cognitive disability

Hip displacement

Seizures

 

Basal ganglia scarring

Thalamic scarring

UL - upper limb; LL - lower limb; GDD - global developmental delay

questions.text: Stranger anxiety develops at
questions.solution: Stranger anxiety develops at 7 months

questions.text: A primigravida gives birth to a term baby. You, as a medical officer, counsel her about breastfeeding. Which of the following is a sign of poor attachment of the baby to the breast?
questions.solution:
Signs of good attachment of baby’s mouth to nipple include

  • The mouth is wide open
  • Most of the nipple and areola are in the mouth and only upper areola is visible
  • The baby’s chin is touching the breast
  • The lower lip everted

Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for 6 months. Complementary foods rich in iron and other micronutrients should be introduced at about 6 months of age. Breastfeeding should continue for at least the first year.

The composition of breast milk varies at different time points of lactation to suit the needs of the baby.

  • Colostrum is secret in small quantities during the first 3 to 4 days. It is thick, and yellow and contains a large number of antibodies, immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. 
  • Transitional milk is the one that is seen after 3-4 days until 2 weeks and has an increased fat and sugar content while the protein and immunoglobulin content reduces.
  • Mature milk is secreted after transitional milk. It is essential for the optimum growth of the baby as it contains all the nutrients. It is thinner and more watery.
  • A mother who delivers before 37 weeks secretes preterm milk that contains proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobulin, and calories as needed by the preterm infant.

questions.text: A 3 yr old male child with left flank pain is diagnosed to have an acute UTI. On USG, the left ureter was found to be duplicated. The most probable site of the opening of ectopic ureter will be?
questions.solution:
Opening of the ectopic ureter in male (most to least common) :

  • Posterior urethra (prostatic) above the external sphincter
  • Seminal vesicle
  • Prostatic utricle
  • Ejaculatory duct
  • Vas deferens

questions.text: In a child, non-functioning Kidney is best diagnosed by
questions.solution:
Renal scintigraphy is the best method to identify a non functioning kidney.

Renograms can be of :

  • MAG 3
  • DTPA

questions.text: Pupils in stage 2 of hypoxic ischaemic encephalopathy show
questions.solution:
Pupils in different stages of HIE :

Stage 1  - Mydriasis

Stage 2 - Miosis

Stage 3 - Unequal, poor light reflex

questions.text: Successful ventilation is determined by
questions.solution:
Successful ventilation is signified by:

  • Adequate chest rise
  • Symmetric breath sounds
  • Improved pink colour
  • Heart rate > 100 beats/min
  • Spontaneous respirations
  • Presence of end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2 should not be zero)
  • Improved tone

questions.text: In a child with Tetralogy of Fallot, with fever and diarrhoea, which is the surest sign of a cyanotic spell?
questions.solution:
The absence of murmur can be considered as a sure sign of Cyanotic spell.

There is a characteristic temporary decrease or absence of systolic murmur during a cyanotic spell because of decreased flow across the right ventricular outflow tract.

questions.text: Differential Cyanosis occurs in which of the following disease
questions.solution:
Differential cyanosis can be caused by

  • Persistent pulmonary hypertension of Newborn
  • Coarctation of Aorta
  • Interrupted aortic arch

questions.text: The feature of breast feeding jaundice is:

choices.text: Occurs in the 1st week after birth in breastfed infants
Supplementation with formula or expressed breast milk is inappropriate even if the infant appears dehydrated

questions.solution:
• Breast feeding jaundice is an early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia which occurs in the 1st week after birth in breastfed infants.
  • It is the result of decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake.
  • Frequent breastfeeding of >10times /24 hr (NOT withholding breastfeeding), rooming-in with night feeding, and ongoing lactation support helps to reduce the incidence of early breastfeeding jaundice.
  • Even when breastfeeding jaundice develops, breastfeeding should be continued if possible.
  • Supplementation with formula or expressed breast milk is appropriate if the intake seems inadequate, weight loss is excessive, or the infant appears dehydrated.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with an upper limb deformity as given in the image below. He has had recurrent respiratory infections and is breathless while walking. You hear a wide split and fixed second heart sound through all phases of respiration. Identify the heart disease likely to be present in this child.
questions.solution:
The heart disease likely to be present in this child is an atrial septal defect (ASD).

The given clinical history along with the image is suggestive of Holt Oram syndrome. The syndrome is characterized by hypoplasia of the thumb, phocomelia, atrial septal defect, and triphalangism. 

Clinical features of ASD include exercise intolerance and failure to thrive although many children are asymptomatic. On auscultation, there is a widely split and fixed second heart sound in all phases of respiration, along with an ejection systolic murmur. Occasionally an ejection click is heard over the pulmonary area.

Chest X-ray shows enlarged right atrium and right ventricle. The diagnosis can be further affirmed in ECG which interprets right ventricular volume overload with normal peripheral vascular resistance. The location and size of the ASD can be confirmed in 2D scanning of the defect. Treatment involves closure of the defect either by surgery or by percutaneous catheter device insertion over the defect. 

Other options:

Option B: Transposition of great vessels (TGV) - ejection systolic murmur of grade 1 or 2 with features of cyanosis and failure to thrive.

Option C: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) - continuous murmur is distinctly heard on auscultation due to systolic and diastolic overloading of the pulmonary artery. 

Option D Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) - pulmonary ejection systolic murmur with a tricuspid flow murmur.

questions.text: A neonate presents with fever, lethargy, abdominal distension, vomiting and constipation. Clinically he was diagnosed as volvulus neonatarum with suspected perforation. Best investigation would be?
questions.solution:
• Plain X ray is the initial investigation of choice to demonstrate free air under diaphragm in suspected cases of perforation.
  • Barium contrast studies with fluoroscopy is the investigation of choice in early stages of volvulus.
  • However in cases of perforation barium contrast is not used because of high risk of peritonitis.

questions.text: What is the shape of caecum in the newborn
questions.solution:
• The shape of caecum in an infant is conical with appendix at the base of the cone
  • Thereafter caecum descends and assumes its round shape

questions.text: The treatment of choice for a primary grade 5 VUR involving both kidneys in a 6 month old boy is

choices.text: Cystoscopy followed by subureteric injection of Teflon

questions.solution:
Treatment of choice of Grade 5 Vesico Ureteric Reflux :

  • Less than 1 year – Antibiotic prophylaxis
  • 1-5 years – Unilateral - Antibiotic prophylaxis
  • 1-5 years – Bilateral – Surgery
  • 1-5 years with scarring – Surgery
  • Above 5 years – Surgery

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presents to the pediatric emergency unit with seizures. Blood pressure in the upper extremity is measured as 200/140 mm Hg. Femoral pulses were not palpable. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution: Isolated upper extremity hypertension with absent or diminished femoral pulses clearly suggest the diagnosis of Coarcation of aorta.

questions.text: All are true regarding tricuspid atresia except

choices.text: Pulmonary oligemia in chest X ray

questions.solution:
Single S2 is present in tricuspid atresia.

Features of Tricuspid Atresia :

  • Underdeveloped Right ventricle
  • ASD or patent foramen ovale
  • Hypertrophy of left ventricle – Left axis deviation
  • Pulmonary oligemia – 90%
  • Normal S1
  • Single S2
  • Murmur grade 2 to grade 3

questions.text: A newborn is being evaluated for anuria. Imaging reveals renal agenesis and pulmonary hypoplasia. The delivery was complicated due to oligohydramnios. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A newborn infant with anuria, renal agenesis, and pulmonary hypoplasia, with a history of oligohydramnios, is suggestive of Potter's sequence

Potter's sequence is characterized by the triad of:

  • Renal agenesis
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia

Option B: Pierre–Robin syndrome: micrognathia, retrognathia, glossoptosis.

Option C: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia: It can present with pulmonary hypoplasia but other features like renal agenesis, anuria will not be seen.

Option D: CHARGE syndrome: Coloboma of the eye, Heart anomaly, choanal Atresia, Retardation, Genital and Ear anomalies.

questions.text: All of the following are considered normal in a newborn except

choices.text: Tuft of hair over LS spine

questions.solution:
A tuft of hair over the lumbosacral spine is not a normal finding in newborns. It suggests an underlying abnormality such as an occult spina bifida, a sinus tract, or a tumor.

Normal skin findings in a newborn:

  • Erythema toxicum – small white papules on an erythematous base, seen 1-3 days after birth. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week.
  • Pustular melanosis – Seen predominantly in black neonates, they contain neutrophils and are present at birth as a vesiculopustular eruption. Lasts for 2-3 days.
  • Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. They tend to disappear within the first year.

questions.text: A male infant born at 34 weeks of gestation by emergency LSCS was found to have the following finding on histopathological examination of his umbilical cord. Anomalies of which of the following systems are most likely to be found in this infant?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of a  single umbilical artery which is associated with an increased risk for an occult renal anomaly.

The histopathological image of the cross-section of the umbilical cord shows 2 vessels as marked, a thin-walled umbilical vein and a thicker-walled umbilical artery. 

 

The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. Anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries.

Trisomy 18 is a common association.

questions.text: You notice a child pulling to the standing position and then shuffling around by holding onto furniture. At what age is this milestone typically attained?
questions.solution: Cruising is an activity in which a child pulls to the standing position and then shuffles around holding onto a piece of furniture. Cruising is attained by 10-11 months.

questions.text:
A 20-month-old child diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is receiving treatment in your clinic. Given below are five statements regarding the treatment. Pick out the incorrect statements.
  1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be started from day 1 of admission.
  2. The stabilization phase would ideally include the first seven days of treatment.
  3. Vitamin A is given daily to overcome micronutrient deficiency.
  4. F-75 feeds can be initiated in split portions.
  5. Promote skin to skin contact with mother to avoid hypothermia.
questions.solution:
Vitamin A is not given daily in the treatment of SAM. It is given on day 1, day 2 and day 14.

The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

Initial stabilization phase: It focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions and requires 2-7 days of inpatient treatment.

Mnemonic: SHIELDED

  • Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia) 
  • Hypothermia
  • Infection
  • ELectrolyte imbalance
  • DEhydration
  • Deficiency of nutrients

Rehabilitation phase: It focuses on rebuilding wasted tissue and generally takes several weeks.

Steps:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (blood glucose level <54 mg/dl): if symptomatic, give 10% Dextrose IV at 5ml/kg. Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care called “kangaroo technique” or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat an infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14.
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
  • Start cautious feeding: Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 feeds. It is low-lactose milk that contains 75 kcal and 0.9 g protein per 100 mL.  After 3 days, transition to F100 feeds is made which is called a catch-up diet. This provides 100 kcal and 2.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 1 week, calories are further increased to 150–200 kcal/kg/day and protein to 4–6 g/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to home-based diet

questions.text: In the pediatric wards, you notice a baby, totally occupied with his little game and a mother trying hard to spoonfeed him. He is busy stacking toy cubes on top of each other and starts gleefully clapping once he makes a tower of 6. What is the likely age that this milestone corresponds to?
questions.solution:
A child can usually make a tower of 6 blocks by 24 months.

A child makes a tower of:

  • 2 blocks by 15 months
  • 3 blocks by 18 months
  • 6 blocks by 2 years
  • 9 blocks by 3 years

Related Pearl: Fine motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
4 months Reaches out for objects with both hands (Bidextrous reach)
6 months
Reaches out for objects with one hand (Unidextrous reach) and transfers objects
9 months Immature pincer grasp
12 months Mature pincer grasp
15 months Imitates scribbling and builds a tower of 2 blocks
18 months Scribbles and builds a tower of 3 blocks
2 years Builds a tower of 6 blocks
3 years Builds a tower of 9 blocks and copies a circle
4 years Builds a bridge with blocks and copies a cross
5 years Copies a triangle and builds a gate with blocks

questions.text: You are sent for active field surveillance of malnourished children to a rural district in central India. Which of the following specific finding would prompt you to make a diagnosis of marasmus?
questions.solution:
Children with marasmus have a voracious appetite, whereas children with kwashiorkor often refuse to eat.

Marasmus is a calorie deficit state and kwashiorkor is a protein deficit state. The signs of low protein manifesting as hypoalbuminemia and edema are characteristically seen in kwashiorkor. 

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Marasmus Kwashiorkor
Seen in infants less than 1 year of age

Seen in older children

(6 months to 3 years of age)
Total calorie deficit Protein deficit
No edema Edema is prominent

Voracious appetite

No apathy

Loss of appetite

Apathy
Severe muscle wasting Muscle wasting mild or absent
Prominent ribs Protuberant abdomen

No Fatty liver

No subcutaneous fat

Fatty liver

Subcutaneous fat preserved

Special features:

  1. Alert
  2. Loose wrinkled skin 
  3. Baggy pant appearance

Special features:

  1. Moon face
  2. Flaky paint dermatosis
  3. Flag sign

The image below shows Flag sign characterised by alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand.

 

The image below shows a child with an old wrinkled old man appearance.

 

The image highlights the differentiating clinical features between marasmus and kwashiorkor

questions.text: A 2-month-old child is brought to your OPD with complaints of diarrhoea. The mother wants to know if she should continue breastfeeding. Which of these components in breast milk, beneficial in intestinal cell maturation and repair, prompt you to advise her to continue breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
The epidermal growth factor present in breastmilk helps in intestinal cell maturation and repair. This is why mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding in an infant affected with diarrhoea. It is also beneficial in luminal surveillance.

Lactoferrin (Option A) helps in immunomodulation, iron chelation, antimicrobial action. It is also an antiadhesive and trophic for intestinal growth. 

Para-aminobenzoic acid (Option C) is present in low levels and offers protection against plasmodium. 

Glutathione peroxidase (Option D) prevents lipid oxidation. 

World Breastfeeding Week is held annually from August 1 to 7 and is supported by WHO, UNICEF, and health ministries. The theme of this year is "Closing the gap: Breastfeeding support for all" - highlighting the importance of recognising and supporting breastfeeding mothers, sharing experiences, and promoting multi-level support through policies, building a breastfeeding-friendly healthcare system, respect for women's autonomy, and community solidarity.

questions.text: The eldest child of a ragpicker from the urban slums of Bandra presents with severe lower limb pain. Examination reveals swelling of costochondral junctions. The X-ray image obtained is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette involving a neglected child (eldest usually) from a poor socio-economic background with bone pains due to subperiosteal haemorrhages and scorbutic rosary (swelling of costochondral junctions) is suggestive of scurvy. 

Radiological features of scurvy:

Early changes

  • The white line of Frankel on the ends of the shafts of the tibia and fibula
  • Wimberger ring sign: Sclerotic rings around the epiphyses of the femur and tibia.

Late changes

  • Trummerfeld zone: Zones of destruction in the femur and tibia
  • Pelkan spur at the cortical end

The image sums up the X-ray features noted in scurvy.

The image attached below shows a child with the scorbutic rosary.

questions.text: A newborn infant develops respiratory distress 2 days after birth. On examination, she is mottled and has weak upper extremity pulses and absent femoral pulses. Investigations reveal the coarctation of the aorta. Which of the following drugs can you use to keep the ductus open medically before surgical repair?
questions.solution:
Alprostadil, a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analogue, can be used to keep the ductus open medically in the coarctation of the aorta.

The ductus arteriosus (the fetal connection between the pulmonary artery and the descending aorta) is functionally closed at 10-15hrs after birth and anatomically closed at 10-21 days after birth.

Survival of newborns with certain heart lesions such as coarctation of the aorta, hypoplastic left heart syndrome and transposition of great vessels depends on the patency of ductus arteriosus. Closure of PDA in such conditions can lead to hypoperfusion, severe hypoxia and cyanosis.

PGE1 is a potent and specific relaxant of ductal smooth muscle. PGE1 analogues like alprostadil, misoprost and rioprostil can be used to keep the ductus open and support systemic blood supply.

In patent ductus arteriosus, the ductus is closed medically by NSAIDS (which inhibit prostaglandin synthesis) like ibuprofen trometamol/ ibuprofen lysine and indomethacin. Morphine can be used to manage respiratory distress  but rarely preferred in a neonate.

questions.text: A primigravida was taken up for emergency cesarean section in view of placental abruption, at 32 weeks of gestation. Immediately after delivery, you dry the baby, clear secretions from the mouth and nose, and provide tactile stimulation. But even after 30 seconds, you note the baby is still gasping for breath and oxygen saturation has not increased more than 92%. Which is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of respiratory distress in a preterm infant is neonatal RDS (hyaline membrane disease). The infant has presented with moderate respiratory distress without any signs of respiratory failure so early continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is the appropriate treatment.

CPAP started at birth is the choice for the management of a preterm infant at risk for respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Early nasal CPAP has shown to lower mortality and risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia. Room air is better than oxygen for the resuscitation of preterm infants, and 100% oxygen is also harmful, causing increased oxidative stress.

The intubate-surfactant-extubate (INSURE) on CPAP technique is recommended for surfactant administration when babies showed signs of RDS and needed more than 30% inspired oxygen to maintain saturation in the normal range.

questions.text: The most common extracranial solid tumor in pediatric age group is_____
questions.solution:
• Neuroblastoma – is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy and also, the most common extracranial solid tumor in children.
  • It is an embryonal cancer of the peripheral sympathetic nervous system.
  • The median age for diagnosis is 22 months and 90% of cases are diagnosed by 5 years of age.
  • Other options:
    • Optic nerve glioma, more properly referred to as juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma, is the most frequent tumor of the optic nerve in childhood.
    • Chloromas, which are collections of myeloid leukemia cells, seen in patients with AML, can occur throughout the neuroaxis.
    • Retinoblastoma is the most common primary malignant intraocular tumor of childhood.

questions.text: What is the most common leukemia you would encounter in a child with the following findings?
questions.solution:
The image shows a typical Down's facies (flattened nose, flat occiput, low set ears, protruding tongue). The most common leukemia in children with Down syndrome is acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Children with Down syndrome are at increased risk of both acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

10% of neonates with Down's syndrome develop transient leukemia or myeloproliferative disorder. These features usually resolve within the first 3 months of life. However, they require close follow-up, because 20–30% will develop typical leukemia (often acute megakaryocytic leukemia) by 3 years of life.

Note:

  • Most common leukemia in Down's syndrome: B-cell Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (overall)
  • The most common leukemia in children <3years of age with Down syndrome is acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
  • Most common AML in Down's syndrome: M7/megakaryoblastic
